fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.bodyText: The V2 rocket that killed 134 people at Hughes Mansions, in London's East End on March 27 1945 was not quite the last of the war to land in Britain (Reviled as outsiders, page 23, April 16). Later the same day, another V2 hit Orpington, in Kent, killing one person. We said in an article about mobile phone technology, Far from content, Online, page 24, April 21, that it had taken 3 two years to get past the 1 million subscriber mark. In fact, 3 took 18 months to pass that mark, in August last year. In March, the company announced that it had more than 3 million customers. An article citing concerns by supermarkets about the antibacterial chemical triclosan, Shops act on scare, page 5, April 16, included Carex among the brands that contained it. Triclosan was removed from Carex in 2001. It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. Readers may contact the office of the readers' editor by telephoning +44 (0)20 7713 4736 between 11am and 5pm UK time Monday to Friday, excluding UK bank holidays. Mail to readers' editor, the Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, UK. Fax +44 (0)20 7239 9997. Email: reader@theguardian.com
